title: Using MCPs to Access Financial Data
audience: CFOs, controllers, FP&A teams, finance leaders

slides.headline: Using MCPs to Access Financial Data
slides.visual: Dark, elegant background with subtle circuit-board patterns transitioning into financial chart lines - deep navy blue with gold accent nodes
slides.speaker_notes: Good morning. I'm Edward Roske, and first - thanks to the team at Caprus AI for hosting today. If you don't know Caprus, you will by the end of this talk. They're the people you call when you want this stuff actually implemented. But more on that later. I've spent 25 years helping CFOs make sense of their data. For most of that time, that meant building reports, writing queries, and begging IT for access to systems. Today I want to show you something that changes the fundamental equation of how finance people interact with their data. We're going to talk about MCPs - and how they let AI do the heavy lifting of pulling, analyzing, and interpreting your financial data. No coding required. Just plain English.

slides.headline: You have more financial data than ever - and less time to use it.
slides.visual: Frustrated professional at a desk surrounded by multiple monitors showing different enterprise applications - ERP on one screen, spreadsheets on another, a consolidation tool on a third
slides.speaker_notes: Here's the situation most of you live in every day. You've got an ERP system. Maybe SAP, maybe Oracle, maybe Dynamics. You've got an EPM tool for planning and consolidation. You've got a general ledger. You've got spreadsheets - lots of spreadsheets. And every one of these systems has its own interface, its own query language, its own way of doing things. The data is there. Getting to it efficiently? That's the problem. You spend more time extracting and formatting data than actually analyzing it. I've watched CFOs spend entire Fridays just getting the numbers ready for Monday's board meeting. That's not a good use of anyone's time.

slides.headline: What if accessing your financial data was as easy as asking a question?
slides.visual: A simple chat interface on a clean screen with the text 'Show me Q3 revenue by region vs. plan' typed into it - minimal, elegant, powerful in its simplicity
slides.speaker_notes: Imagine this. You open a chat window - Claude, ChatGPT, whatever your AI of choice is - and you type: 'Show me Q3 revenue by region versus plan.' And it comes back with the answer. Not a link to a report. Not instructions on how to build a query. The actual answer, pulled live from your EPM system. That's what we're going to talk about today. And the technology that makes it possible has a name: MCP.

slides.headline: What MCP is. How it connects to finance. What it can do. Where it's going.
slides.visual: Clean, minimal dark background with four glowing pathway nodes connected by light trails, each node representing a section
slides.speaker_notes: Here's our agenda. First, I'll explain what MCP actually is - in plain English. Second, we'll look at how it connects to the financial systems you already use - EPM, ERP, general ledgers, market data. Third, I'll show you real examples of what this looks like in practice - pulling reports, finding anomalies, doing analysis through conversation. And fourth, we'll talk about where this is headed and what it means for the Office of the CFO. Let's get into it.

slides.headline: Part 1: What is MCP - and why should finance care?
slides.visual: A glowing USB-C connector rendered in abstract digital art style, floating in dark space with data streams flowing through it
slides.speaker_notes: Let's start with the basics.

slides.headline: MCP is the USB-C of AI - one standard connection to everything.
slides.visual: Split image - left side shows a tangle of old proprietary cables and connectors, right side shows a single clean USB-C cable - the contrast is stark
slides.speaker_notes: If you remember the old days of computing - and I do, unfortunately - every device had its own connector. Printers had parallel ports. Mice had serial ports. Keyboards had their own thing. It was a mess. Then USB came along and said: one connector, everything works. MCP does the same thing for AI. It stands for Model Context Protocol, but you don't need to remember that. What matters is what it does: it creates a standard way for AI to connect to your data. Before MCP, if you wanted AI to talk to your ERP system, you needed custom development. A dedicated integration. Developer time. Budget fights. With MCP, you build one connector and any AI tool can use it. One standard. Universal access. Every major AI company supports it - Anthropic, OpenAI, Google, Microsoft. This isn't a proprietary play. It's an industry standard.

slides.headline: You ask a question. The AI gets the answer from your systems. You never touch the plumbing.
slides.visual: Simple before/after split - left side shows a person navigating through multiple system login screens, menus, and query builders; right side shows the same person typing a plain English question and getting an answer
slides.speaker_notes: Here's what MCP does in practice. You ask the AI a question - 'What were our top 10 expense categories in Q3?' The AI uses MCP to connect to whatever system has the answer - your ERP, your data warehouse, your EPM tool. It pulls the data, organizes it, and gives you the answer. You never see the connection. You never write a query. You never log into the source system. Think of it like this: before MCP, every time you needed data from a different system, you needed someone who knew that system's language. MCP gives the AI fluency in all of them. So instead of asking your IT team or your FP&A analyst to pull the data, you just ask the AI directly. (Your FP&A team will thank you. Or possibly panic. Either way.)

slides.headline: FactSet. S&P Global. Microsoft. Oracle. They're already in production.
slides.visual: A landscape of major company logos - FactSet, S&P Global, Microsoft, Oracle - with 'In Production' badges, alongside bold stats: '800+ institutional users' for FactSet, 'Dynamics 365 connected' for Microsoft
slides.speaker_notes: I want to be clear: this isn't a concept or a roadmap slide. FactSet launched an MCP connector for financial data - 45 firms and over 800 institutional users adopted it within months. S&P Global connected Capital IQ data to Claude through MCP. Microsoft built an MCP connector for Dynamics 365. Companies are building these for Oracle EPM, for Snowflake, for accounting platforms. Every major AI company supports the standard. When I say 'the industry has moved,' I mean the industry has moved. The question isn't whether this technology is ready. It's whether you are.

slides.headline: Part 2: Connecting MCP to your financial systems.
slides.visual: A digital bridge made of light connecting a traditional stone financial building to a futuristic glass data center
slides.speaker_notes: Now that you know what MCP is, let's talk about where it plugs in - the systems you actually use every day.

slides.headline: EPM. ERP. General Ledger. Data warehouse. BI tools. MCP connects to all of them.
slides.visual: An ecosystem map showing interconnected financial systems - EPM, ERP, GL, Data Warehouses, BI Tools, Treasury, Tax, Market Data - with MCP as the central hub
slides.speaker_notes: Let's map out the financial system landscape. Most organizations have some combination of these: an ERP for transactions - SAP, Oracle, Dynamics, NetSuite. An EPM system for planning, budgeting, and consolidation - Oracle EPM, OneStream, Anaplan. A general ledger. A cloud data warehouse - Snowflake, Databricks, BigQuery - where you're centralizing your financial data. BI tools - Power BI, Tableau - for visualization and reporting. Treasury management. Tax systems. And external market data feeds. Here's the key: every one of these can be MCP-connected. And because MCP is a universal standard, you don't need a separate integration for each one. Connect your data warehouse, and every AI tool in your organization can query it. The major vendors are already building these connectors. You don't have to start from scratch.

slides.headline: Microsoft already built an MCP connector for Dynamics 365. SAP and Oracle are following.
slides.visual: A Dynamics 365 dashboard morphing into a conversational AI interface - structured data transforms into natural language responses
slides.speaker_notes: Let's start with ERP. Microsoft introduced their Dynamics 365 MCP connector at Build 2025. It gives AI access to ERP data and business actions - purchase orders, journal entries, vendor records, inventory data - all accessible through natural language. And this isn't read-only. With proper authorization, an AI agent could post a journal entry, create a purchase order, or run an inventory adjustment. (I know. Some of you just felt a chill. We'll talk about controls later.) SAP and Oracle are building similar capabilities. By the end of this year, most major ERPs will have MCP connectors available.

slides.headline: MCP turns your EPM system into a conversational planning and consolidation tool.
slides.visual: A financial consolidation tree with multiple entities flowing into a parent - rendered as a flowing digital river of data points merging together
slides.speaker_notes: Now EPM - this is close to my heart. I spent two decades in this space. Think about what you do in EPM: financial consolidation, planning, budgeting, forecasting, scenario modeling. All of it involves pulling data, running calculations, reviewing results, and making adjustments. With MCP, you could say to the AI: 'Run the Q4 forecast using the aggressive growth assumptions and compare it to the base case.' And it would connect to your Oracle EPM or OneStream instance, run both scenarios, pull the results, and present you with a comparison. No navigating through menus. No building report definitions. Just a question and an answer. This isn't theoretical - Revvence has already published research on extending Oracle EPM into AI-driven workflows using MCP.

slides.headline: Your general ledger has answers buried in it. MCP helps AI dig them out.
slides.visual: A massive ledger book opening to reveal streams of digital data flowing upward, transforming from traditional accounting entries into data visualizations
slides.speaker_notes: The general ledger is where the truth lives. Every transaction, every journal entry, every adjustment. But querying a GL effectively requires knowing the chart of accounts, understanding the coding structure, knowing which segments to filter on. Most of you rely on someone else to pull this data. MCP changes that. You ask: 'What were our top 10 expense categories in Q3, and how do they compare to Q2?' or 'Show me all journal entries over $50,000 posted in the last week of the quarter.' The AI handles the query. You get the answer. And it can flag things a human might miss - like unusual patterns in journal entries that could indicate errors or (let's be honest) something worse.

slides.headline: Your data warehouse already has the answers. MCP lets AI ask the questions.
slides.visual: A massive cloud data warehouse icon connected to a BI dashboard, both feeding into an AI conversational interface
slides.speaker_notes: A lot of you have invested heavily in cloud data warehouses - Snowflake, Databricks, BigQuery. You've centralized years of financial data there. And you've got BI tools - Power BI, Tableau - sitting on top. The problem? Getting ad hoc answers still requires either technical skills or waiting for someone with technical skills. MCP eliminates that bottleneck. You ask in plain English: 'What was our customer acquisition cost by channel for the last four quarters, and how does it trend?' The AI translates that into the right query, runs it against your warehouse, and presents the result. No waiting for IT. No submitting a ticket. And the numbers stay consistent with your dashboards because the AI pulls from the same data models. It becomes a natural language front-end for your entire analytics stack. (Which is what you were promised BI tools would be 15 years ago, but here we are.)

slides.headline: No fragile integrations. No constant rework. That's the MCP promise.
slides.visual: A cracked fragile glass bridge labeled 'Custom Integration' shattering on the left - versus a solid steel bridge labeled 'MCP' standing firm on the right with data flowing smoothly
slides.speaker_notes: Let me address something that's probably in the back of your mind. You've been here before. 'Connect System A to System B.' You build the integration. It works. Then someone updates an API. Or the schema changes. Or you upgrade the ERP. And suddenly your integration breaks and nobody knows why until the Monday morning report doesn't run. We've all lived through this. MCP is fundamentally different because it's a standard. When your ERP vendor updates their system, they update their MCP connector. Your AI tools don't care - they're still speaking the same standard. It's like how upgrading your phone doesn't break your USB-C cable. The standard doesn't change when the systems behind it evolve.

slides.headline: FactSet launched the first production MCP connector for financial data. 800+ institutional users in months.
slides.visual: A financial terminal screen overlaid with flowing real-time market data streams - stock tickers, charts, analyst estimates - converging into a conversational interface
slides.speaker_notes: Here's where it gets really interesting for anyone who works with external data. FactSet launched what they called the industry's first production MCP connector for financial intelligence. Within months, 45 firms and over 800 institutional users adopted it. Through MCP, AI can now access FactSet's fundamentals, estimates, ownership data, M&A transactions, pricing data, and more - all through natural language. You could ask: 'What's the consensus EPS estimate for Microsoft, and how has it changed over the last three quarters?' And it pulls the answer from FactSet in real time. No terminal. No separate login. No export-to-Excel dance. (I know some of you just got emotional about that last one.)

slides.headline: S&P Global brought Capital IQ data into Claude. Financial research just changed forever.
slides.visual: The S&P Global and Anthropic logos connected by a glowing MCP bridge, with data streams flowing between them
slides.speaker_notes: In July 2025, S&P Global and Anthropic announced the integration of S&P Global's financial data into Claude via MCP. This includes Capital IQ financials, earnings call transcripts, company profiles, and more. Think about what this means. An analyst can now ask: 'Summarize the key themes from Amazon's last three earnings calls and flag any changes in management's tone around capital expenditure.' And the AI goes and gets the transcripts, reads them, and gives you the analysis. That used to be a junior analyst's entire Friday. Now it takes 30 seconds. (The junior analyst can now do actual analysis. Imagine that.)

slides.headline: The real power? Connecting MCP to your own proprietary financial data.
slides.visual: A secure vault door slightly ajar with golden light emanating from within - representing proprietary internal financial data being made accessible but secure
slides.speaker_notes: FactSet and S&P Global are impressive. But here's what matters most for the people in this room: connecting MCP to your own data. Your internal financial data - the stuff that lives in your ERP, your EPM system, your data warehouse. That's where the competitive advantage is. Any company can query public market data. But only you can ask: 'How does our actual manufacturing cost per unit compare to our budget assumptions by plant location for the last six months, and where are the biggest variances?' That requires access to your internal data. And that's exactly what a custom MCP connector enables. You build it once, and then every AI tool in your organization can use it. One connection, universal access.

slides.headline: Part 3: Agentic AI - when the AI doesn't just answer, it acts.
slides.visual: A robotic hand and a human hand reaching toward each other, but the gap shows flowing financial data instead of a spark - collaborative, not replacement
slides.speaker_notes: Now we get to the part that's genuinely transformative. So far I've been talking about AI answering questions. Important, but that's just the beginning. Let's talk about what happens when the AI doesn't just answer questions but actually does work.

slides.headline: You give it a goal. It figures out the steps.
slides.visual: A workflow diagram showing an AI agent autonomously moving through steps - pulling data, analyzing, comparing, flagging anomalies, drafting a report - each step lighting up sequentially
slides.speaker_notes: Let me define 'agentic' because it gets thrown around a lot. A regular AI interaction is: you ask a question, you get an answer. One step. Agentic AI is different. You give it a goal - like 'prepare the monthly close analysis' - and it figures out the steps on its own. It pulls the trial balance. It compares to prior month and prior year. It identifies significant variances. It researches the causes. It drafts the narrative. Multiple steps, working autonomously. It's the difference between asking someone to hand you a wrench and asking someone to fix the sink. MCP is what makes this possible, because it gives the AI the ability to actually interact with your systems - not just read from them, but take actions.

slides.headline: Observe. Think. Act. Report. That's how an AI agent works.
slides.visual: A circular flow diagram showing the agentic cycle - Observe, Think, Act, Report - with MCP connections at each step
slides.speaker_notes: Here's the pattern. Step one: Observe. The AI reads data from your systems via MCP - trial balances, budgets, forecasts, transaction details. Step two: Think. It analyzes what it found - calculates variances, identifies trends, spots anomalies. Step three: Act. It digs deeper - running a drill-down query, pulling supporting documentation, checking a related system. Step four: Report. It presents its findings in whatever format you need. And here's the key: steps one through three can repeat multiple times before it reports. The AI might pull data, notice something unexpected, dig deeper, find the root cause, then report. Just like a good analyst would. Except it does it in minutes, not days. (And it never asks for a raise.)

slides.headline: "What drove the $2.3M variance in COGS?" - from question to root cause in seconds.
slides.visual: A chat interface showing a conversation where the user asks about a COGS variance and the AI responds with structured analysis including line items and root causes
slides.speaker_notes: Let me walk you through what this looks like. Imagine you're reviewing the quarterly results and you see Cost of Goods Sold is $2.3 million over budget. In the old world, you email the cost accounting team, wait a day, get a spreadsheet back, dig through it, send follow-up questions. With an MCP-connected AI agent, you type: 'What drove the $2.3M variance in COGS this quarter?' The agent connects to your ERP, pulls the detailed COGS transactions. It compares to budget by category. It identifies that raw material costs in Plant 3 spiked in August due to a supplier price increase. It pulls the purchase orders to confirm. It checks whether the new pricing is reflected in the Q4 forecast. And it reports all of this back to you in about 30 seconds. One question. Complete answer.

slides.headline: An AI agent that monitors your close process and flags what needs attention.
slides.visual: A monthly close checklist with items being checked off by an AI agent icon - some glow green (complete), one yellow (in progress), a few pending
slides.speaker_notes: Here's another scenario. Month-end close. Every controller's favorite time. (I'm kidding. Nobody's favorite time.) Imagine an AI agent that monitors the close process through MCP. It checks which entities have completed their submissions. It compares intercompany balances and flags mismatches. It reviews journal entries for completeness. It identifies accounts with unusual balances. And it sends you a summary: '14 of 16 entities have completed their close. Intercompany is out of balance by $47K between Entity 5 and Entity 12. Three unusual journal entries flagged for review.' You go from spending hours checking status to getting a proactive briefing. The agent did the work. You make the decisions.

slides.headline: "Prepare the board deck data package" - and the agent pulls from five systems to build it.
slides.visual: A polished executive dashboard emerging from a conversational AI interface - charts, KPIs, and narrative text assembled automatically with data streams from multiple sources
slides.speaker_notes: One more scenario that hits close to home for CFOs. Board meeting prep. You need a data package: revenue trends, margin analysis, cash flow summary, headcount metrics, forecast vs. actual. That data lives in five different systems. Normally, it takes your FP&A team a week to assemble. With an AI agent connected via MCP to your EPM, ERP, HRIS, and data warehouse, you say: 'Prepare the Q3 board data package.' The agent pulls revenue and margin data from your EPM system. It gets cash flow details from your ERP. It grabs headcount from your HR system. It compiles the forecast comparison. It generates the charts and narrative summaries. It doesn't replace the judgment your FP&A team brings. But it eliminates the manual data gathering so they can focus on the analysis and storytelling that actually matters.

slides.headline: Ask a follow-up. Then another. The AI maintains context and keeps digging.
slides.visual: A conversation thread showing increasingly deeper questions - starting broad and drilling down through follow-ups - each answer pulling more specific data
slides.speaker_notes: This is the one that tends to blow people's minds in demos. The AI maintains context across a conversation. You start with: 'How did EMEA perform in Q3?' It pulls the results. You say: 'Break it down by country.' It does. 'What happened in Germany in August?' It drills into Germany's August numbers. 'Was that driven by volume or price?' It calculates the volume/price mix. Each question builds on the last. The AI remembers the context. It's like having a conversation with your best analyst - except this analyst has instant access to every system and never needs to say 'let me get back to you on that.' (Which, let's be honest, is the most expensive sentence in corporate finance.)

slides.headline: Part 4: Real use cases for the Office of the CFO.
slides.visual: A CFO's desk viewed from above - laptop open to an AI interface, coffee cup, financial documents semi-transparent suggesting the physical giving way to digital
slides.speaker_notes: Let's get practical. Here are the specific use cases where MCP-connected AI is already delivering value for finance organizations.

slides.headline: Consolidation shouldn't require a week. With MCP, the AI does the heavy lifting.
slides.visual: Multiple subsidiary financial statements flowing into a funnel producing a single consolidated view - streams of data merging with currency symbols from different countries
slides.speaker_notes: Financial consolidation. Multi-entity, multi-currency, intercompany eliminations, minority interests. It's complex. It takes time. And most of the time is spent on mechanics, not judgment. An MCP-connected AI can pull trial balances from all entities. It can identify intercompany imbalances. It can flag elimination entries that don't match. It can check currency translation rates. It can generate the consolidated statements and highlight any line items that look unusual compared to prior periods. Your team still makes the judgment calls. But the grunt work - the pulling, checking, reconciling - that's automated. What used to take a week can be done in a day.

slides.headline: Planning cycles measured in months should be measured in days.
slides.visual: A planning spreadsheet transforming into a dynamic AI-driven scenario model - static cells morph into flowing adjustable parameters with cascading calculations
slides.speaker_notes: Planning and budgeting. The annual budget process at most companies takes three to four months. (And by the time it's done, the assumptions are already stale. But we all pretend otherwise.) With MCP-connected AI, you can fundamentally accelerate this. The AI can pull historical actuals, apply trend analysis, generate initial budget assumptions, and create a draft plan in hours instead of weeks. And when the CEO says 'what if we grow 15% instead of 10%?' - which always happens, usually at 4:47 PM on a Friday - the AI can rerun the entire plan with new assumptions immediately. It connects to your EPM system, adjusts the drivers, recalculates the cascade, and shows you the impact. No more 'we'll have that reforecast for you next week.'

slides.headline: An AI agent can analyze variances across 500 cost centers before your team finishes their coffee.
slides.visual: A heat map of a large organization - hundreds of cost centers as a grid, colors from green (favorable) to red (unfavorable) - an AI magnifying glass hovers over the red spots
slides.speaker_notes: Variance analysis is where most FP&A teams spend a huge portion of their time. And it's largely mechanical - compare actual to budget, calculate the difference, identify the big ones, research the causes. An MCP-connected agent can do this across your entire organization in minutes. Every cost center. Every line item. Every entity. It identifies the material variances, ranks them by impact, and starts researching the drivers - all before your team has opened their laptops. This doesn't replace the analyst's job. It upgrades it. Instead of spending 80% of their time finding the variances and 20% analyzing them, they can flip that ratio. (Your FP&A team didn't go to school to be human calculators. Let them do actual analysis.)

slides.headline: Cash flow forecasting gets smarter when the AI can see receivables, payables, and history simultaneously.
slides.visual: A river of cash flowing through a landscape representing a company's operations - tributaries flowing in (receivables) and streams flowing out (payables) with an AI watchtower overseeing
slides.speaker_notes: Cash flow forecasting. It's critical and it's hard. Because the data lives everywhere - AR, AP, payroll, debt service, capex commitments. With MCP, an AI agent can pull from all of these simultaneously. It can look at your receivables aging and predict collection timing based on historical patterns. It can check your AP schedule. It can incorporate your debt service calendar. And it can produce a rolling 13-week cash forecast that updates automatically as new data comes in. When the CFO asks 'can we fund that acquisition in Q2?' the answer comes with supporting analysis, not a request for two more weeks.

slides.headline: AI doesn't get tired. It can review every journal entry, not just a sample.
slides.visual: A magnifying glass over a massive spreadsheet of journal entries - certain rows highlighted and flagged by an AI icon indicating detected anomalies
slides.speaker_notes: Audit and compliance. Here's something that should make every controller's ears perk up. Traditional audit procedures rely on sampling. You check a sample of transactions because checking all of them is impractical. MCP changes that equation. An AI agent can review every journal entry. Every single one. It can flag entries that match known risk patterns - round numbers, entries just below approval thresholds, entries posted at unusual times, entries to unusual account combinations. It's not replacing your auditors. It's giving them superpowers. Total population testing instead of sampling. That's a fundamental shift in audit quality. (Your external auditors will either love this or hate this. Probably both.)

slides.headline: Reports that write themselves - and actually explain what the numbers mean.
slides.visual: A traditional paper financial report dissolving into particles that reform as an interactive AI-generated digital report with dynamic charts and narrative insights
slides.speaker_notes: Here's one that saves time every month. Management reporting. With MCP-connected AI, the agent can pull the numbers from your EPM system, generate the standard reports, and - here's the important part - write the commentary. 'Revenue increased 12% driven by strong performance in the consumer segment, partially offset by a decline in enterprise due to delayed contract renewals.' That's not a human writing that. That's an AI that pulled the data, analyzed the drivers, and wrote the narrative. Your team reviews and refines it instead of creating it from scratch. And if anyone has questions about the report? They ask the AI. It has full context because it built the report from the source data.

slides.headline: Part 5: What does it actually take to get started?
slides.visual: A clean architectural blueprint rendered in an accessible style - showing a simple path from 'where you are' to 'where you want to be' with clear milestones
slides.speaker_notes: I know some of you are thinking: 'This sounds great, but what's the catch?' Fair question. Let me talk about what it actually takes.

slides.headline: Start with what vendors have already built. Build custom connectors for your unique data. Start small.
slides.visual: Three columns on a clean background - 'Use What Exists' (vendor connectors), 'Build What You Need' (custom connectors for internal systems), and 'Start Small' (pilot use case) - each with a simple cost/effort indicator
slides.speaker_notes: There are three paths, and most organizations will use all three. Path one: Use what already exists. FactSet, S&P Global, Microsoft Dynamics - they've already built MCP connectors. If you use those platforms, you can start today. Literally today. Path two: Build connectors for your internal systems. This is where your IT team - or the nice people over at Caprus AI - come in. Building an MCP connector for your data warehouse or EPM system is a focused project - weeks, not months. Not years. It's not a full system implementation. It's closer to building a report writer that speaks a standard language. And if you need an existing connector configured for your environment, that's exactly what firms like Caprus do. Path three: Start small. Pick one use case. Variance analysis. Board prep. Cash forecasting. Prove the value with one process before you try to connect everything. The organizations getting the most value aren't doing big-bang rollouts. They're starting with one painful process and expanding from there.

slides.headline: This doesn't mean 'give the AI the keys to the kingdom.' Governance is built in.
slides.visual: A fortress wall with a digital gate - open but monitored, with shields representing SOX, access controls, and audit trails visible - controlled access, not wide open
slides.speaker_notes: I want to address the elephant in the room. When I tell CFOs 'we're going to let AI access your financial systems,' I can see the blood drain from their faces. So let me be clear. This is not uncontrolled access. You control exactly which data the AI can see, which actions it can take, and who can use it. Read-only access for most users. Write access only for specific, approved workflows with proper authorization. Full audit logging for every query and every action - every question asked, every data point returned. Your SOX auditors can review exactly what the AI accessed and when. And honestly, it's more auditable than most of the processes it replaces. (When was the last time you had a complete audit trail of who opened which spreadsheet on the shared drive and changed what? Right.)

slides.headline: You don't have to build everything. A lot of this is already built and in production.
slides.visual: A landscape showing available MCP financial connectors - FactSet, S&P Global, Microsoft, CData, open-source tools - with 'Available Now' markers
slides.speaker_notes: Let me give you a reality check on what's available right now - not on a roadmap, not in beta, but in production. FactSet has a production connector with 800+ institutional users. S&P Global integrated Capital IQ data into Claude. Microsoft has a connector for Dynamics 365 ERP. CData built connectors for Xero and other accounting platforms. There are open-source connectors for various accounting tools. Financial Datasets has a connector for stock market data. And new ones are launching every month. For custom internal systems, companies are building their own - and the standard makes this significantly easier than building traditional integrations. The ecosystem is growing fast. By the time you finish your next planning cycle, the options will have doubled.

slides.headline: Part 6: Where is this going?
slides.visual: A road stretching into a bright horizon, made of data streams, the horizon glowing with possibility - optimistic and grounded
slides.speaker_notes: Let's look ahead.

slides.headline: The future isn't AI replacing finance teams. It's finance teams with AI teammates.
slides.visual: An organizational chart where some roles are human icons and others are AI agent icons - working side by side, connected by data flows - collaborative, not hierarchical
slides.speaker_notes: Gartner says agentic AI will transform finance. Deloitte is calling it one of the top tech trends for 2026. But let me be clear about what this actually looks like. The future is not AI replacing your finance team. The future is your finance team working alongside AI agents. One agent monitors the close process. Another handles variance analysis. A third manages cash forecasting. A fourth does continuous audit monitoring. They all connect to your systems through MCP, and they coordinate with each other. Your people handle the judgment, the strategy, the stakeholder communication, the 'what should we do about this?' Less time in spreadsheets, more time doing the work that actually requires a human brain. That's not a dystopian future. That's a better job.

slides.headline: Three things to do this quarter: experiment, identify, plan.
slides.visual: A clear bold checklist with three items on a clean dark background - each with a simple icon - practical, actionable, no fluff
slides.speaker_notes: So what should you actually do? Three things. First: Experiment. Pick one use case - variance analysis, report generation, data exploration - and try it with an MCP-connected AI. FactSet and S&P Global integrations are available today in Claude. Start there. See what's possible. Second: Identify. Look at your finance processes and identify where the most time is spent on data gathering versus analysis. Those high-gathering processes are your MCP opportunities. Where are your people spending 80% of their time just finding the numbers? Start there. Third: Plan.
